content.value: Philadelphia is lifting its indoor mask mandate week under criteria established by a COVID-19 alert system it announced two weeks ago. That means that residents may unmask in all but select environments, such as schools, public transportation and health care settings.
This brings the city in with federal guidance issued last week, which also allows residents who are not immunocompromised to unmask.

But the break from indoor masking stands on shaky ground. The city’s algorithm is designed to make All Clear — the transmission tier that allows residents to unmask — hard to achieve, an Inquirer analysis found. In the past two years, the city would only have hit All Clear for only five weeks in the summer of 2021.
Here’s why.

value.text: Philadelphia’s COVID alert system ties public health measures like indoor masking, testing and vaccination verification requirements to COVID-19 cases, test positivity and hospitalizations.
Extreme Caution is the highest alert tier. Businesses have to verify vaccination status of customers as a condition of entry and enforce indoor masking.

Caution is the next highest tier. Unvaccinated patrons may test in lieu of vaccination. There is no difference between Extreme Caution and Caution for vaccinated customers. The mask mandate would remain in place for everyone.
value.text2: Just under half of all weeks in the past two years would have been designated **Caution**.

value.text: One tier down is Mask Precaution Only, which requires businesses to enforce an indoor mask mandate but not a vaccine mandate.
All Clear is the final alert tier, and the only one with no public health interventions associated with it. Only 5 weeks in the past two years would have been mask-free.
The City’s algorithm is designed to be wary and produce this outcome. The alert level depends on COVID hospitalizations and three metrics that are tied to reported COVID cases.
Over the past two years, hospitalizations have never hit All Clear. That means that all three other factors need to perfectly align to produce an overall designation of All Clear.

The case average presents a snapshot of COVID prevalence in the community. The case rate of change tracks whether cases have seen sharp increases in the past week or not. They don’t always align, because small increases among small numbers can register as large percentage increases.
When both these case measures have hit All Clear simultaneously, cases have been low and on the decrease. That was true in summer 2021, and that is true today.
Overall, positivity aligns most closely with the overall alert tier, followed by COVID hospitalizations.

content.value: The city included hospitalizations because “it's a metric into the severity of whatever variant is spreading at the time,” said James Garrow, communications director for the city’s public health department.

Hospitalizations also serve as the breaks on the system since they lag cases, he said. A fall in cases today will only register as a fall in hospitalizations a few weeks later. Relaxing restrictions too quickly “could lead to a second peak,” Garrow said.

For hospitalizations to hit All Clear, the number of people in Philly hospitals would have to fall under 50. All probable and confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Philly’s hospitals contribute to this number, and the city has fallen below this threshold on exactly two days over the course of the past two years.
Neither of those days were Mondays, when the city looks at the numbers to set the COVID-19 alert level for the week.

By contrast, the federal government’s system, which places greater emphasis on hospitalization metrics than the city’s does, sets its thresholds higher. More than 160 COVID-19 patients indicates medium risk; over 320 pushes Philadelphia toward the high risk category, which requires universal masking, an Inquirer analysis found.
The federal government’s system, released last week, differs from the city’s in four other key ways:
The CDC system prioritizes measures of hospital strain over case metrics to measure spread in the community.
CDC thresholds are chosen based on their ability to predict COVID deaths. The city’s thresholds are designed to keep tabs on surging cases.
The CDC recommends masking in the highest alert tier, whereas the city requires masking in all but the lowest tier.
The CDC places the onus on individuals to follow guidance, whereas the city expects businesses to enforce these rules.
The CDC has de-emphasized reported cases and test positivity partly because the results of home tests don’t make it into either of those numbers.

The city accounts for this reporting bias in its calculation of the positivity rate by only looking at the results of molecular tests, but the algorithm is nevertheless heavily skewed toward metrics that gauge spread even though the city’s data will paint an increasingly incomplete picture of spread going forward.

Despite these caveats with reported cases, “it's worthwhile, looking at them,” said Anuradha Paranjpe, professor of medicine at Temple University. “It will be a leading indicator of where we have another variant.”

At present, “people are still struggling to get that home test. So it's a useful figure for us now,” Garrow said. As home tests become more available, “I wouldn't be surprised if we changed it, but we don't have any concrete plans to do that right now.”
Where the federal and city requirements do converge is in their accommodation of the unvaccinated.

Public health mitigation measures have to find the sweet spot between interventions that effectively reduce spread and those that minimize restrictions and economic disruption, said Neal Golstein, professor of epidemiology and biostatistics at Drexel.
Vaccination is the most effective tool to reduce disease spread and hospital strain, but vaccine verification is the city’s last resort under the city’s current system.

“From a public health perspective, you want the least restrictive means necessary to control whatever the health condition that you're concerned about, whether it's a pandemic or some other outbreak,” he said. But “the least restrictive means necessary — that is very subjective based on the individual.”

At their most basic, both the city and federal systems are designed to ramp up restrictions and down going forward depending on spread and severity of disease, and public health professionals generally agree with that principle. Where there is disagreement among experts is in how to message public health restrictions going forward, which metrics to track and how much importance to give them, and how to proportionally increase mitigation measures in response to risk.
Those questions don’t have easy answers. But one thing is certain: unmasking today does not mean that the pandemic is over.
“CDC Director Rochelle Walensky has been very clear to say we can give people a break from masks now,” Paranjpe said. “But we should have them handy should we need them again.”

value.value: Data are sourced from the [Philadelphia Department](https://www.opendataphilly.org/dataset/covid-cases/resource/85fead1a-0ec3-4856-98a9-27ba4fa941ee) [of Public Health](https://www.phila.gov/programs/coronavirus-disease-2019-covid-19/guidance/covid-19-response-levels/) and the [Pennsylvania Department of Health](https://data.pa.gov/Covid-19/COVID-19-Aggregate-Hospitalizations-Current-Daily-/kayn-sjhx).
The methodology below is identical to the one used by the Philadelphia Department of Public Health.

All four metrics — test positivity, case average, case rate of change and COVID-19 hospitalizations —  are calculated on Mondays to determine the alert level for the rest of the week. Alert tiers are only shown for weeks when all four metrics are available, starting March 30, 2020.

A limitation with this retroactive analysis is that test data is revised constantly as results come in from labs. As a result, analysis applied retroactively is performed on more complete data on tests and cases than what would have been available in real-time. If the analysis had been performed on Monday each week over the past two years, the tier classification may have been different at the time to what is shown here. Data were pulled on Feb. 23, 2022 for the graphics above.

Test positivity is calculated only using molecular test results based on the day of specimen collection. To account for the incompleteness of the most recent testing data, the Philadelphia Department of Public Health only considers data through the previous Friday in its calculation of the alert level.

Only molecular tests are considered in the positivity calculation because home tests may be self-reported to the department on a voluntary basis, and are counted as antigen tests in those circumstances. The self-reported nature of those antigen tests introduces a sampling bias, so the agency disregards all antigen tests in calculating a positivity rate.

The department counts positive test results from both PCR and antigen tests by the date of specimen collection, again with a two day lag to account for incomplete data. Cases are considered as a seven-day average.

Hospitalization numbers are reported to the state directly by medical providers every day and include all probable and confirmed cases of COVID-19. Only hospitalizations within Philadelphia County boundaries are counted. The state Department of Health counts antigen and PCR positives in its numbers. Only the daily number reported on Mondays is considered in the calculation of the alert tier. Data unavailable for Dec 20, 2021 statewide due to a “data processing error”.
